newsitem.title: UK: Fall in British retail sales eases fear of consumer boom.
newsitem.headline: Fall in British retail sales eases fear of consumer boom.

text.p: British retail sales dipped in September, official figures showed on Wednesday, providing evidence that while high street shops are busy there is little danger of a runaway consumer boom.
The Office for National Statistics said retail sales fell 0.3 percent in September compared with a 0.9 percent rise in August.
But longer-term measures showed consumer spending is still growing fast. The ONS said sales were 3.5 percent higher than in September a year ago.
This was a welcome boost to the ruling Conservatives who are eager to restore a strong sense of economic wellbeing before the general election, which must be held by May 1997.
Government officials pounced on the figures as evidence the consumer-led recovery is still on track.
"The fall in September sales followed a rise in August, and the two months together suggest conditions in the high street are bustling," said Treasury minister Angela Knight.
A sharp fall in sales of clothing and footwear was the main culprit in dragging down overall retail activity in September.
Prices in this sector rose sharply in September and City economists said retailers appeared to be finding it difficult to coax thrifty consumers into paying higher prices.
"Consumers are not yet willing to abandon the bargain- hunting mentality and still balk at paying higher non-sale prices," said David Coleman, chief economist at CIBC Wood Gundy.
Sales of textiles, clothing and footwear fell 3.0 percent in September after jumping 2.2 percent in August. Clothing and footwear prices leapt by 5.2 percent in September.
With the election looming, the government will take heart from the recent spate of data which shows the economy growing steadily, consumer spending rising but little sign of inflationary pressures.

Coupled with the latest unemployment figures which showed the jobless total at a five-year low in September, retail sales data suggests the "feel-good" factor, or consumer confidence, is gradually making a comeback.
But although high street spending remains solid, a return to the eighties-style consumer boom is still a long way off, economists said.
"There's a firm underlying trend there but we're not back to the frothiness we saw in the late '80s," said Deutsche Morgan Grenfell economist Ciaran Barr.
And the slowdown in sales will give Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke more ammunition to resist calls by Bank of England Governor Eddie George to raise interest rates.
Clarke has cut interest rates four times since last December to their present 5.75 percent level is under considerable political pressure to resist calls for a further increase before the election.
